title: A systematic review of AI, VR, and LLM applications in special education: Opportunities, challenges, and future directions
abstract: Abstract The rapid advancements in modern technologies have opened new possibilities for enhancing educational experiences for students with Special Educational Needs and Disabilities (SEND). This paper conducts a systematic review of 139 studies on the integration of AI, VR, and LLMs in Special Education. Using a deductive thematic analysis framework, it identifies key themes and challenges to synthesize the current state of knowledge and propose future research directions. The findings underscore the transformative potential of AI and Immersive Technologies in fostering personalized learning, improving social engagement, and advancing cognitive development among SEND students. Additionally, current SEN methodologies and practices are defined, teachers'attitudes toward inclusion and technology adoption, and the prevailing technological tools utilized, based on various syndromes and disorders. Challenges such as ethical considerations, accessibility barriers, and resource limitations are also discussed. Moreover, this study explores tailored technological tools specifically designed to meet the unique needs of these students. The paper concludes with limitations, recommendations for cross-sector collaboration and inclusive policies to ensure these technologies are effectively utilized to prioritize and enhance learning experiences for SEND students, as well as future directions.

Abstract
The rapid advancements in modern technologies have opened new possibilities for 
enhancing educational experiences for students with Special Educational Needs and 
Disabilities (SEND). This paper conducts a systematic review of 139 studies on the 
integration of AI, VR, and LLMs in Special Education. Using a deductive thematic 
analysis framework, it identifies key themes and challenges to synthesize the current 
state of knowledge and propose future research directions. The findings underscore 
the transformative potential of AI and Immersive Technologies in fostering person-
alized learning, improving social engagement, and advancing cognitive development 
among SEND students. Additionally, current SEN methodologies and practices 
are defined, teachers’attitudes toward inclusion and technology adoption, and the 
prevailing technological tools utilized, based on various syndromes and disorders. 
Challenges such as ethical considerations, accessibility barriers, and resource limita-
tions are also discussed. Moreover, this study explores tailored technological tools 
specifically designed to meet the unique needs of these students. The paper con-
cludes with limitations, recommendations for cross-sector collaboration and inclu-
sive policies to ensure these technologies are effectively utilized to prioritize and 
enhance learning experiences for SEND students, as well as future directions.

1 Introduction
In 1975, the Education for All Handicapped Children Act (EAHCA), renamed 
the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), stood for the educa-
tional rights of all children, regardless of their disability (Individuals with Dis-
abilities Education Act, 2024). In 1994, in Salamanca, Spain, 92 governments 
and 25 organizations embraced inclusive education under the motto"Education 
for All"(The Salamanca Statement and Framework for Action on Special Needs 
Education, 2024). Article 24 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of 
Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD) underscores the demands of those with dis-
abilities for quality and tailored education (United Nations, 2024). The CRPD 
of 2006 champions SEND individuals’ participation and social inclusion, safe-
guarding against societal misconduct (UNICEF(a), 2024). Nevertheless, SEND 
children and young people are still facing social stigma and prejudice, especially 
those living in poverty (Servili & Bermejo et al., 2023).
In the last 45 years in the USA, there’s been a 45% increase in Special Educa-
tion students—from 3.6 million in 1976–77 to 7.3 million in 2021–22 (Pendharkar 
et  al., 2024). About 40% of public schools report a lack of Special Education 
teachers, while 32% of children benefit from IDEA’s learning disability support. 
Autistic children’s representation rose from 1.5% in 2000–01 to 12% in 2021–22 
(Schaeffer et al., 2024). In 2020–21, 14% of SEND youths aged 14–21 dropped 
out and 5.4% were home-schooled. According to UNESCO, 15% of German and 
59% of Hong Kong parents view SEN students as classroom disturbances; 37% 
of Queensland’s SEN students leave regular schools (UNESCO, 2020). Globally, 
1 billion people have some form of disability, including nearly 240 million chil-
dren (UNICEF(b), 2024). Organizations promote inclusivity, using AT (Assistive 
Technology) or ICTs (Information and Communication Technologies) in educa-
tion for personalized learning, communication, and cognition, enhancing SEND 
students’social, communicational, and problem-solving skills.
Assistive Technologies (AT) is defined by the International Classification of 
Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) as"any technology … improving the 
functioning of a person with a disability", whereas the International Organiza-
tion for Standardization (ISO) states AT is"any product"aimed at SEND individu-
als for protection, advocacy, and enhancing quality (Borg et al., 2015). SEN stu-
dents should achieve social and emotional fulfillment in class, attaining parity 
in competencies (Black-Hawkins et al., 2017). Mapping the difficulties a student 
may face, whether is a SEN student is not, as they are depicted in Fig.  1, show 
the challenges that ATs can potentially overcome. Newly emergent or established 
technologies, such as LLMs and VR or AR in the forms of ATs may ensure inclu-
sion of all students within the classroom. This heterogeneity with the class con-
sists of typically developed children, SEN students (Autism Spectrum Disorder, 
Down Syndrome and more), student with disabilities (motor or visual impair -
ments, asthma, heart disease and more), immigrants, as indeed all these children 
are called to function and interact as a unity, ensuring inclusion is established, 
through the aid of ATs.

As a means of interaction, LLMs, often called the’Big Bang’phenomenon in 
AI and NLP, have captivated the scientific community (Kalyan, 2024; Liu et al., 
2023a). AI enables systems to perform tasks requiring human intelligence, while 
NLP allows computers to understand and generate human language. Together, 
they empower LLMs to revolutionize language-based interactions. Figure  2 illus-
trates the brief historical evolution of LLMs, as they are sophisticated models, a 
type of neural network composed of vast parameters and trained on a vast amount 
of unstructured data, like books, websites, texts and more (Mbakwe et al., 2023). 
Their ability to reason, generate multilingual text, summarize, answer questions 
are their most well-established abilities (Chung et al., 2022; Li et al., 2024; Liu 
et al., 2023b; Ozkaya, 2023).
LLMs have found fertile ground for application in many scientific fields (Liu 
et al., 2023a). Especially in education, which shapes future generations, learning 
and teaching strategies are affected by AI and LLMs and thus LLM-based educa-
tional systems seem to have promising potential (Darayseh, 2023; Li et al., 2023). 
The extensive amount of knowledge in which LLMs have been trained is an out-
standing asset, along with their human-like responses (Cardona et al., 2023; Li 
et al., 2023). According to Li’s review paper, Mathematics (Luo & Specia, 2024), 
Writing (Fan et al., 2023), Programming (Liventsev et al., 2023), Reasoning (Ho 
et al., 2022) and knowledge-based (Arefeen et al., 2023; Vu et al., 2023) are the 
main domains of applying LLMs in the field of Education. Their integration into 
Special Education is particularly crucial due to the field’s complexity, requiring 
thoughtful and deliberate actions.

This review highlights the significant advancements in the application of VR, 
AR, and LLMs in Special Education. However, while these technologies are being 
implemented individually, it remains uncertain how they could be effectively inte-
grated in a combined manner for SEND students. To address this uncertainty, this 
study focuses on the following Research Questions (RQs):
(RQ1). How is the Scientific Community exploring the application of VR and 
AR in Special Education?
(RQ2). How are LLMs being utilized to address the needs of students in Special 
Education, as reflected in the literature?
(RQ3). How can the integration of LLMs and VR create new opportunities for 
Special Education?
(RQ4). How do existing studies conceptualize the success and challenges of 
using VR and LLMs in Special Education?
(RQ5). What SEN methodologies and practices are defined by the Scientific 
Community to support the implementation of VR, AR, and LLM technologies 
within them?
(RQ6). What factors influence teachers’attitudes toward the inclusion of SEN stu-
dents and their adoption of these technologies in Special Education?
(RQ7). What are the dominant technological tools, including Immersive technol-
ogies and LLMs, that provide benefits for individuals with Special Needs based 
on their specific syndrome or condition?
Given these pressing challenges and opportunities in the integration of modern 
technologies in Special Education, this study employs a deductive thematic analy -
sis approach to systematically explore existing literature. By focusing on predefined 
themes, the methodology aims to uncover patterns and insights aligned with the 
study’s research questions.
2  Methodology
This paper employs the deductive thematic analysis framework developed by 
Thomas and Harden (Thomas & Harden, 2008), as a methodological basis for con-
ducting a systematic review on the integration of AI, VR, and LLMs in Special 
Education. It serves both as a methodological guide for thematic analysis and as a 
resource for synthesizing research in this field. The study aims to identify, evaluate, 
and synthesize the research questions outlined (RQ1–RQ7), identifying key themes 
and challenges to assess the current state of knowledge and propose future research 
directions. Thematic analysis was chosen for its flexibility and systematic approach

in identifying patterns and themes within the selected literature, making it particu-
larly suitable for understanding the complexities and recurring concepts in these 
domains.
2.1  Databases and timeframe
The literature search was conducted using three academic databases: Arxiv and Sci-
enceDirect, because these databases aggregate articles from a wide variety of scien-
tific journals, offering broad and diverse coverage. Their selection ensures access to 
multidisciplinary research, enabling a comprehensive review of the topics explored 
in this study. Future research could include additional databases, such as Web of 
Science or Lens, to provide broader perspectives and further enrich the findings. The 
search was carried out in two phases, from December 1, 2023, to February 29, 
2024, and again from September 16, 2024, to October 8, 2024. These timeframes 
ensured the inclusion of the most up-to-date and relevant studies.
2.2  Systematic review process
This study employs a systematic review methodology to investigate the integration 
of AI, VR, and LLMs in Special Education. The process consisted of the following 
steps:
Initiation Based on Research Questions:
1. This study explores key research questions (Q1–Q7) that guide the investigation 
into the applications, opportunities, and challenges of VR, AR, and LLMs in Spe-
cial Education. It also examines SEN methodologies and practices, the inclusion 
of SEND individuals, teachers’attitudes toward these technologies, and the role 
of technological tools—including immersive technologies and LLMs—tailored 
to specific syndromes and disorders.
Defining Inclusion Criteria:
2. To ensure the relevance and quality of the studies included in the review, the fol-
lowing criteria were applied:
• Language: Only studies published in English were included.
• Source Credibility: Studies must be from established and credible aca-
demic sources with direct relevance to the domains of LLMs, VR, AR and 
Special Education.
• Relevance to Themes: The studies must focus on the application of VR, AR, 
and LLMs in educational settings, particularly for students with special edu-
cational needs and disabilities (SEND) and contribute meaningfully to identi-
fying key themes.

2.3  Minimizing bias
To ensure the reliability of the findings, two independent reviewers participated in 
the data extraction and coding process. Discrepancies in coding and theme identi-
fication were resolved through discussion. This approach helped minimize bias and 
increase the credibility of the results.
3  Findings
This section presents the findings derived from the systematic review and deduc-
tive thematic analysis, focusing on Immersive Technologies and LLMs through 
relevant studies, addressing their integration into Special Education and the chal-
lenges associated with their implementation. Additionally, it explores SEN meth-
odologies and practices, as well as teachers’ attitudes toward technology, and 
the application of technological tools categorized by syndromes and disorders. 
This approach provides a comprehensive perspective on the role of these technolo-
gies in Special Education, as their integration is of high importance.
3.1  VR and AR in special education
VR has emerged as a powerful tool in Special Education, offering personalized 
learning environments that cater to the unique needs of students with disabilities. 
By enabling educators to modify teaching strategies, VR allows for the adaptation of 
instructional content to align with the cognitive, sensory, and motor abilities of indi-
vidual learners (Chiazzese et al., 2019; Luna et al., 2018; Mangina et al., 2018; Par -
maxi, 2023). This adaptability is particularly advantageous for students with ADHD, 
and other learning disabilities, as immersive VR environments enhance engagement, 
minimize distractions, and provide structured, interactive experiences that reinforce 
learning concepts (Chiazzese et al., 2019; Mangina et al., 2018). Furthermore, VR 
integrates scaffolding and multimodal feedback, allowing students to progress at 
their own pace while receiving real-time guidance and corrections—an essential 
factor in fostering self-regulated learning and improving knowledge retention (Par -
maxi, 2023). Research also highlights the effectiveness of VR-based interventions 
19150 Education and Information Technologies (2025) 30:19141–19181
in literacy and language learning, particularly for students with ADHD, by creating 
engaging, gamified learning experiences that sustain attention and motivation (Luna 
et al., 2018). While some studies explore AR applications for students with ADHD 
and literacy interventions (Chiazzese et al., 2019; Mangina et al., 2018), VR remains 
a distinct and emerging tool with promising implications for inclusive education.
Additionally, VR significantly contributes to accessibility in Special Education, 
empowering individuals with hearing and speech impairments. A major challenge 
faced by these individuals is the lack of a standardized visual representation of 
Sign Language (SL), which often creates barriers to social inclusion (Cheok et al., 
2019). Advances in technology, particularly in hand gesture recognition, have led 
to the development of innovative projects such as ISENSE, which visualizes sign 
languages to support university students (Bisio et  al., 2024). Studies focusing on 
SL integration in VR environments aim to enhance social interaction for individu-
als with hearing and speech impairments, demonstrating the progress made in this 
field (Aziz & Othman, 2023; Brega et al., 2014; Ghoul & Othman, 2022; Kasapakis 
et al., 2023; Naglot & Kulkarni, 2016; Quandt, 2020; Raval & Gajjar, 2021; Sandler 
& Lillo-Martin, 2006; Vaitkevičius et al., 2019; Velmathi & Goyal, 2023).
Empowering communication skills, VR has been integrated into arts-based inter -
ventions to foster cognitive and social skills in students with special needs. The 
Open Doors to the Arts project, for instance, creates a 360-degree VR environment 
designed to promote exploration and social integration among autistic students 
(Heintzelman & Fogt, 2023). Research suggests that combining VR with the arts not 
only enhances critical thinking, concentration, and creativity but also enriches the 
learning experience by incorporating immersive and engaging activities. Comple-
menting this, technologies like Kinect and 3D cameras facilitate game-based learn-
ing, further contributing to the development of motor, cognitive, and language skills 
(Allcoat & von Mühlenen, 2018; Kusumaningsih et  al., 2022; Sheehan & Katz, 
2013).
The extensive body of research on VR in Special Education underscores its 
potential to support SEN students in acquiring essential skills, improving social 
engagement, and developing speech and emotional intelligence (Bisio et al., 2024; 
Gerhátová et al., 2014; Ghoul & Othman, 2022; Ironsi, 2023; Luca et al., 2023; Safi  
et al., 2023; Wasserman et al., 2019). Additionally, VR has proven to be particularly 
effective in adapting to diverse learning contexts, especially in STEM education, 
where it facilitates hands-on, interactive learning experiences (Ke et al., 2022; Moon 
et al., 2020; Sokolikj et al., 2023). Motion-based games that utilize body tracking 
technology further enhance engagement by promoting the development of motor 
coordination and interaction skills, which are crucial for students with disabilities 
(Kourakli et al., 2017).
VR has firmly established itself as a transformative tool in Special Educa-
tion, providing immersive, adaptable, and personalized learning experiences 
that address the diverse needs of students with disabilities. As an already well-inte-
grated technology, VR plays a pivotal role in shaping inclusive educational envi-
ronments. Moving forward, its potential could be further amplified through inte-
gration with emerging technologies, such as Large Language Models (LLMs), to

3.2  AI and LLMs in special education
AI benefits children with impairments across devices (Garg & Sharma, 2020). Liu’s 
review (2012–2021) identifies AI as a key educational tool, enhancing personalized 
learning and teaching competencies (Liu et al., 2023a). Generative AI’s uniqueness 
and sophisticated outcomes have made it a megatrend (Martin et  al., 2024; Tlili 
et  al., 2023). Martin highlights ChatGPT’s significant research interest and AI in 
Education (Castelli & Manzoni, 2022; Liu et al., 2023b), supporting critical think -
ing and enriching learning experiences (Darvishi et al., 2022; Dwivedi et al., 2023; 
Essel et  al., 2024; Kasneci et  al., 2023; Liu et  al., 2023a; Rahman & Watanobe, 
2023; Rahman & Islam et. al, 2023; Rospigliosi, 2023; Tlili et al., 2023).
AI has made significant strides in Special Educational Needs (SEN), offering 
personalized learning and support. AI adapts to the specific learning needs of SEN 
students, creating individualized pathways for instruction. Studies by Cardona and 
Garg highlight AI’s ability to provide tailored resources, helping learners overcome 
various challenges (Cardona et al., 2023; Garg & Sharma, 2020). Furthermore, AI 
fosters engagement and emotional support, reducing isolation and empowering stu-
dents. AI tools also enhance the learning process through NLP, improving knowl-
edge acquisition and assessment (Zoana et al., 2023).
For visually impaired learners, AI tools enhance interaction and cognition by 
adapting to user needs. AI systems designed for this purpose function as cognitive 
extensions, allowing visually impaired students to navigate their environment more 
independently (Xie et al., 2024). However, studies have revealed biases in AI sys-
tems, particularly chatbots, which tend to depict people with disabilities as having 
more limitations compared to non-disabled users (Urbina et al., 2024). Addressing 
these biases is crucial to ensure fair and inclusive AI-driven educational tools.
In autism, AI has proven especially useful for early diagnosis and intervention. 
AI-driven tools such as NLP and speech analytics provide quantitative insights into 
speech and language patterns, improving diagnostic accuracy (Trayvick et al., 2024). 
Additionally, AI models analyze behavioral and biological markers, such as eye gaze 
and MRI, to detect autism earlier and offer targeted interventions (Pandya et  al., 
2024). Speech frameworks like MT-Net leverage AI to screen for mental disabilities, 
processing speech data to achieve high diagnostic accuracy (Meng et al., 2022).
AI also plays a role in behavior recognition for autistic individuals, using eye-
tracking data and machine learning to assess behaviors and customize interven-
tions (Jeyarani & Senthilkumar et al, 2023). Vision-based AI models like the Video 
Swin Transformer further enhance autism-related behavior recognition (Deng et al., 
2024). Robotic interventions utilizing LLMs have also been developed to assist chil-
dren with autism, delivering dynamic, personalized content during therapy sessions 
(Mishra et al., 2024).
In addition to autism, AI and LLMs are being used to improve text accessibil-
ity for individuals with cognitive impairments by simplifying complex texts into

Easy-to-Read formats (Martínez et  al., 2024). These advancements in AI support 
a more inclusive educational environment, ensuring that learners with various dis-
abilities have access to resources tailored to their needs. As AI continues to evolve, 
addressing biases and ensuring accessibility will be key to its successful integration 
in special education (Almufareh et al., 2024).
The advancement of AI and Large Language Models (LLMs) has already 
shown remarkable potential in enhancing personalized learning, accessibility, 
and inclusion in Special Education. However, their true impact can be ampli-
fied through integration with Immersive Technologies. This convergence opens 
new avenues for research, encouraging the scientific community to explore syn-
ergistic applications that optimize learning outcomes, foster social interac-
tion, and address cognitive and emotional challenges. By embracing this holistic 
approach, the integration of LLMs, and Immersive Technologies has the poten-
tial to reshape Special Education, ensuring that learners with diverse needs have 
access to equitable, effective, and engaging learning opportunities tailored to 
their unique abilities.
3.3  VR and LLMs in special education
VR enhances ASD children’s social skills through activities like physical education 
(Mokmin & Ridzuan, 2022) and storytelling (Ke et al., 2022), while AI integrates 
into STEM and music education (Martin et al., 2024; Wang et al., 2024). Southgate 
explores AI and VR’s impact on Science education engagement and performance 
(Southgate, 2019), a direction further investigated by Martin (Martin et al., 2024). 
Affective Computing (AfC) analyzes human emotion for educational integration 
(Ludlow, 2015), with Jurado introducing a Virtual Human (VH) mimicking human 
emotional and cognitive dynamics, featuring a range of expressions and engaging in 
conversations enhanced by GPT3 (Llanes-Jurado et  al., 2024). However, applying 
VR/AR and LLMs in Special Education lacks a clear framework, underscoring the 
need for inclusion (Llanes-Jurado et al., 2024).
BERT accelerates the humor abilities of Virtual Voice Assistants (VA) and VAs, 
enhancing personalized jokes and feedback but facing limitations (Annamoradnejad 
& Zoghi, 2020; Mottini & Chowdhury, 2019). It was also utilized for Intelligence 
Virtual Assistance, virtual well-being coaching, and interactive language learn-
ing, despite speech-to-text errors and limited training data (Savelieva et al., 2020; 
Uppoor et al., 2022; Winata et al., 2021).
VAs have evolved with the implementation of LLMs (GPT- 3 and GPT- 4): in 
Higher Education for personalized and adaptive systems, in mobile phones, as 
improved learning systems, learning English, in Metaverse for virtual interactions

3.5  Special education methodologies and practices
SEN students with mild disabilities are enrolled in mainstream classrooms and thus 
positively influenced by their classmates, as relationships are forged, beneficial for 
both parties (Gottfried, 2014; Horoi & Ost, 2015; Huang et al., 2021; Pan & Luo, 
2023; Rangvid, 2019; Schwab, 2015). Nevertheless, SEN children on the verge 
of an emotional outbreak, disturbing the learning process (Balestra et  al., 2022; 
Egalite, 2019). Even among SEN children, there is unequal treatment, as parents 
with ASD children report dissatisfaction with the school community, highlighting 
the lack of qualified school staff, in comparison to DS (Down Syndrome) children, 
who are more likely to attend regular classrooms, while receiving additional sup-
port (Herwegen et al., 2018). ASD children and people with various disorders expe-
rience self-isolation (Bossaert et al., 2012), as well as self-destruction and mental 
issues (O’Hagan et al., 2021). ASD people can meet educational goals, especially at 
upper educational levels (Goodall, 2018), yet Home education is advocated in many 
countries, as in the USA 2.5 million children are learning at home (Ray, 2024). It’s

This is an approach to how the theory of Socio-Constructivism occurs during the

by a game-based learning strategy is also advocated (Johnson-Glenberg et al., 2014; 
Karadimitriou & Roussou, 2011), as well as curriculums and educational plans, 
which should also be adapted to the distinctive personality of each SEN student (Zir-

Parental involvement is encouraged in Israel, but gaps remain in improving 
inclusion policies (Orly, 2015). In comparison with Palestine, educators have the 
willingness, yet there is a profound lack of infrastructure, as well as economic and 
political instability and other issues (MacKenzie et al., 2023). Russia is still in the 
process of forming inclusive educational environments (Valeeva, 2015). In advanced 
economies, like Germany and Sweden inclusion seems to be applied with a diver -
gent approach. The federal states in Germany do not have a unified policy and an

Sweden promotes inclusion for most children, provided they can reciprocate to the 
basics. Any kid can receive assistance in the learning process, without being char -

Inclusion policies vary globally, as there is no unified framework, as highlighted by 
previous studies. However, VR technologies have the potential to transcend geo-
graphical barriers, in which people of all nationalities and religions can connect 
remotely, utilizing LLMs as a powerful means of communication.

3.6  Attitudes of teachers toward special education and technology
Inclusion is highly valued, as teachers form an environment in which SEN students 
explore and develop cognitive skills (Moberg et al., 2020; Savolainen et al., 2012; 
Voinea & Purcaru, 2015). Teachers’ Attitudes Towards Inclusion (ATI) indicate the 
feasibility of integrating SEN students into school communities (Ai et  al., 2022; 
Moberg et al., 2020). Educators classroom management skills are essential, though 
experienced teachers may exhibit negative ATI and younger teachers may face low 
self-esteem issues (Bandura, 2012; Gülsün et al., 2023). Furthermore, due to SEN 
students with EBD (Emotional and Behavioral Disabilities) teachers are inclined to 
abort and change schools (Gilmour & Wehby, 2020). According to O’Hagan, teach-
ers cope with SEN students unsuccessfully (O’Hagan et  al., 2021). They demon-
strate a deficiency in implementing practical interventions for SEN students (Web-
ster & Blatchford, 2019). Home education is a common educational practice, yet 
parents are burned out of adopting various roles in their household, along with the 
prime education of their children (Daniels et al., 2017). SEN Teachers seem to be on 
the verge of emotional fatigue, in comparison with volunteers, who express posses-
siveness, while interacting with disabled people (Sagone & Caroli, 2014).
Teachers in France are thoroughly researched toward ATI. A contradictory defini-
tion of “selection function” acts as an assessment tool of the worthiness of each stu-
dent to achieve learning goals. This term is also in line with the principle of medi-
ocrity, as a general means of discrimination against the abilities of SEN students 
(Khamzina et al., 2021). Educators seem to be the prime agents of instability and 
uncertainty (Krischler & Cate, 2019; Levy & Khoury-Kassabri, 2022). Various con-
siderations are to be raised in terms of management and inclusion of SEN students 
in a moral, warm, safe, and trusting learning environment.
Recent research on Teacher-AI Collaboration (TAC) highlights the potential of 
LLMs to enhance teachers’capacity in various educational tasks. Teachers perceive 
LLMs as supportive tools that can assist with grading, student progress tracking, and 
personalized learning, without replacing their critical instructional roles (Lee et al., 
2024). They appreciate AI’s ability to analyze real-time data to offer tailored educa-
tional resources but emphasize the need for maintaining human oversight in inter -
preting data and making instructional decisions (Owoseni et  al., 2024). Concerns 
persist around the socio-emotional aspects of teaching, as AI may struggle to handle 
complex emotional dynamics effectively (Xuefei et al., 2024). Furthermore, teach-
ers express a need for professional development to improve AI literacy and various 
concerns in AI integration (Lee et al., 2024; Owoseni et al., 2024). The frameworks 
proposed for integrating LLMs into teacher training focus on automating content 
generation for learning objectives and offering personalized feedback, though con-
cerns remain about the oversimplification of feedback (Barno et al., 2024; Lee et al., 
2024). Teachers advocate for collaboration with expert educators to refine AI-gener-
ated insights (Xuefei et al., 2024).

3.7  Technological means for people with special needs: Customized applications 
and devices
Designing an educational system for people with special needs using AI and immer-
sive technologies is a significant and sensitive task. Here are several considerations 
based on various special needs:
 1. Visual Impairments: Considerations for individuals with blindness or severe 
vision impairments should encompass a range of assistive technologies, includ-
ing text-to-speech software, smart glasses (Mukhiddinov & Cho, 2021), screen 
readers, and Braille displays (Hori & Okada, 2017). Immersive technologies 
need to be adaptable, providing audio descriptions for visual content to ensure 
inclusivity (Afonso-Jaco & Katz, 2022). Those with low vision can benefit 
from features like high contrast, large text, and voice commands. AI-powered 
and GPS-based applications play a vital role in helping individuals recognize 
objects and people, navigate different environments, and advocate social engage-
ment (Sameer et al., 2024). Additionally, haptic devices (Papadopoulos et al., 
2015) and wearable technology (Leong & Lim, 2022), offer valuable options 
for enhancing accessibility and independence for these individuals.
 2. Hearing Impairments: Visual or vibrating alerts can replace auditory signals 
(Dim et al., 2022), while closed captioning and sign language interpretation 
should be integrated into video content (Suo et al., 2024). AI-driven lip-reading 
technologies could also be a novel addition (Rajab & Hashim, 2023). Moreover, 
sound amplifiers, cochlear implants (Essaid et al., 2024; Eden & Leibovitz-
Ganon, 2022), telecoil systems are established technologies in conjunction with 
AI that can be of great value asset to them.
 3. Cognitive Disabilities: Individuals with cognitive disabilities might benefit 
from a simplified interface and content, with clear and concise instructions. 
Immersive technologies can be used to create predictable and less distracting 
environments (Wenk et al., 2023). AI can be used to adapt learning content to 
the user’s pace and understanding (Zhao et al., 2022). Indeed, the goal for these 
people is to learn, communicate and perform daily tasks independently through 
cognitive improvement in their daily life routines.

 4. Motor Disabilities: Technology should provide a diverse range of assistive 
devices and solutions for people with motor disabilities. For those with limited 
mobility or fine motor skills, touchless input options like eye-tracking or voice 
commands can be vital (Borges et al., 2022; Ramos et al., 2022). Adaptive hard-
ware and customizable interfaces that cater to individual mobility needs should 
be considered (Floreani et al., 2022; Gannouni et al., 2022). AI and immersive 
technologies could embrace a leading role in accommodating emotional and 
mental fulfillment, abolishing any physical barrier (Creed et al., 2023).
 5. Learning Disabilities: AI can provide personalized learning experiences tai-
lored to the individual’s learning style and pace. Techniques like multisensory 
approaches (Gharaibeh & Dukmak, 2022), immediate feedback, and step-by-
step guidance can be beneficial. Immersive technology can offer practical, 
hands-on experiences in a controlled, repeatable environment (Flores-Gallegos 
et al., 2022). The learning process should be accomplished in line with social 
inclusion and mental empowerment, fully adapted to the special needs of these 
people.
 6. Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD): ASD is a well-researched disorder in the 
fields of robotics, VR and AI. Technological means should prioritize concen-
tration, motivation and trust through Empathetic AI (Fletcher-Watson & Bird, 
2020; Nagy, 2022), Educational Apps, Digital therapeutics (Chu et al., 2023; 
Jeong et al., 2023; Wu et al., 2023) and therapeutic activities. For users on 
the autism spectrum, customizable sensory settings (to reduce or eliminate 
overwhelming stimuli) and structured, predictable interfaces are important. 
Immersive technologies can help practice social situations or routines in a safe 
environment (Mosher et al., 2022).
 7. Psychological/Emotional Disorders: For individuals with anxiety, depression, 
or PTSD, a system should provide a stress-free, comforting environment. AI-
powered psychotherapy tools (Raile, 2024), wearable technology (Kang & Chai, 
2022) and mental health Apps promoting relaxation and reducing emotional 
overload is vital (Balcombe & Leo, 2022). Furthermore, Digital journals, VR 
Therapy (Wiebe et al., 2022), AI-based mood tracking, meditation, or analyz-
ing psychometric traits can potentially boost the mentality (Pellert et al., 2024). 
Privacy, security, and an easy way to pause or exit the experience can help users 
feel safe.
 8. Speech Impairments: For users with speech difficulties, alternative communi-
cation methods such as text-based input, the selection of pre-made phrases, or 
AI-driven predictive text can enhance interaction. AI-based logotherapeutic

communication devices, selecting words or letters with eye or muscle move-
ments (Kasapakis et al., 2022; Redondo et al., 2022).

offer non-verbal communication aids, while TouchChat HD and Choiceworks 
use visual aids for routine understanding (Sigafoos et al., 2014). Floreo helps

4  Discussion
Hristovska acknowledges developing practical strategies for SEN children, stating 
that inclusion is “a continuous, integral, educational process is the way to accept-
ance, care, respect, for children with special education needs in regular schools, 
promoting socio-emotional learning where children who have different needs and 
capabilities will enable a level of learning and tailored to their characteristics 
whilst using different strategies of learning… School communities build open, 
cooperative, flexible, socio-emotional environments” (Hristovska & Jovanova-
Mitkovska, 2010).
The Ministry of National Education outlines five inclusion principles: empathy 
and respect for diverse student groups, individual curriculum adaptation, interactive 
teaching strategies —which can be greatly enhanced using VR and LLMs—, profes-
sional collaboration, and parental involvement in the learning process (Rachmawati 
et al., 2016). However, the implementation of VR and LLMs for Special Education 
is unmapped. Emotional and educational high demands of SEN students reinforce 
the establishment of a robust and precise framework (Rapport et al., 2004).
In addressing the research questions posed, this study derives significant con-
clusions regarding the application of VR, AR, and LLMs in Special Education, as 
outlined below. The findings reveal that the implementation of technological solu-
tions in this field is inherently multidimensional, encompassing teaching environ-
ments, learning strategies, the evolving role of teachers—particularly in terms of 
their acceptance of these technologies—and the application of tailored technologi-
cal tools, often designed to address specific syndromes. Highlighting these aspects 
is of paramount importance, as it empowers the effective implementation of these 
technologies and enhances their impact on educational outcomes for students with 
Special Needs.

Research Question RQ1: VR and AR in education and Special education The first

Souchet et al., 2023).
Research Question RQ2: AI and LLMs in education and special education Similarly, 
RQ2, which examines how LLMs are utilized to meet the needs of students in Spe-
cial Education, reveals their ability to create adaptive learning experiences and sim-
plify complex texts for cognitive impairments (Cardona et al., 2023; Martínez et al., 
2024). LLMs support behavioral recognition, early diagnosis, and therapy, particu-
larly for autistic students, using tools like eye-tracking and speech analytics, as well 
as robotic applications (Deng et al., 2024; Meng et al., 2022). However, biases in 
LLM outputs and the need to ensure equitable access remain critical issues (Alm-
ufareh et al., 2024). Despite these concerns, the potential for personalized learning 
and emotional support provided by LLMs positions them as valuable tools in Spe-
cial Education.
Research Question RQ3: VR and LLMs in special education As discussed in RQ3, 
the integration of VR and LLMs in Special Education holds the potential for trans-
formative opportunities. However, there are no comprehensive studies that clearly 
integrate VR, AR, and LLMs specifically for Special Education. While several stud-
ies explore these technologies individually or in general education contexts (Abadie 
et al., 2024; Chamola et al., 2023), this study highlights a lack of unified frameworks 
or specific research addressing their combined application in Special Education for 
SEND students. Once the scientific community systematically applies these tech-
nologies, clearer insights into the opportunities they can create—such as enhanced 
inclusion, personalized learning, and emotional support—are likely to emerge.
Research Question RQ4: challenges in applying LLMs and immersive technolo -
gies The research query RQ4 examines how existing studies conceptualize the suc-
cess and challenges of using VR and LLMs in Special Education. These technolo-
gies present unique challenges, including the lack of clear frameworks, accessibility 
barriers, and ethical concerns and more, as thoroughly outlined above. However,

Research Question RQ5: special education methodologies and practices Outlining 
the landscape of Special Education, inclusion in mainstream classrooms is often 
regarded as the ultimate goal, as it fosters both social and academic development 
(Pan & Luo et. al, 2023; Rangvid, 2019). However, this objective is frequently 
accompanied by significant challenges, such as behavioral management difficulties 
and instances of unequal treatment among SEND students (Herwegen et al., 2018). 
For some families, homeschooling has emerged as a viable alternative, primarily 
due to dissatisfaction with the adequacy of mainstream education in meeting their 
children’s needs (Ray, 2024). Moreover, the mental health strain experienced by 
educators underscores the pressing need for supportive tools, such as Large Lan-
guage Models (LLMs), to enhance communication, sustain emotional well-being, 
and improve the overall educational environment for SEN students (Owoseni et al., 
2024). This paper aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the field of Spe-
cial Education by examining methodologies and practices endorsed by the scien-
tific community, offering valuable insights to enhance inclusion and support for stu-
dents with SEND people. Indeed, it emphasizes the need for these technologies to be 
adapted to the prevailing circumstances depicted above.

nology The findings highlight several challenges and opportunities related to 
teachers’negative attitudes toward inclusion (ATI), low self-esteem among younger 
teachers, and the behavioral challenges posed by SEN students with Emotional and 
Behavioral Disabilities (EBD) contribute to significant difficulties (Bandura et. al, 
2012; Gilmour & Wehby, 2020; Gülsün et al., 2023). Additionally, a lack of proper 
training in implementing inclusive practices and the prevalence of emotional fatigue 
exacerbate these issues (Sagone & Caroli, 2014; Webster & Blatchford, 2019).
On the other hand, research on Teacher-AI Collaboration (TAC) highlights 
the potential of technologies such as Large Language Models (LLMs) and AI to 
enhance teachers’capabilities (Lee et  al., 2024; Owoseni et  al., 2024). Moreover, 
teachers recognize the potential of VR, AR, and MR technologies in fostering stu-
dent engagement, although issues related to accessibility and inclusion for SEN 
students remain critical barriers (Pérez-Muñoz et al., 2024; Tlili et al., 2022).These 
findings underscore the great promise that these technologies hold when effectively 
implemented in Special Education, highlighting the importance of targeted profes-
sional development programs and the creation of accessible, inclusive solutions to 
empower teachers.

4.1  Limitations
The integration of Immersive Technologies and LLMs in Special Education offers 
a transformative approach, significantly enhancing personalized learning, emo-
tional engagement, and inclusion. Despite their immense potential, these technolo-
gies come with inherent limitations. While several aspects, such as teachers’ lack of 
training, emotional strain, and accessibility barriers, have already been highlighted 
as challenges, these elements have been further delineated to provide a clearer 
and more structured perspective. Challenges address overarching systemic issues, 
whereas limitations focus on specific practical constraints that hinder effective 
implementation, ensuring a comprehensive understanding of the obstacles in apply -
ing these technologies:
1. Technical Barriers: Immersive technologies often demand high-end infrastruc-
ture and technical expertise. For instance, Mehrfard highlights the prohibitive 
costs of VR systems, limiting their scalability, particularly in low-resource set-
tings (Arian et al., 2019). Additionally, Korkut notes the absence of standardized 
frameworks, which creates inconsistency in applying these tools effectively in 
educational settings (Korkut & Surer, 2023).
2. Privacy and Security: Data protection is a significant concern in virtual learning 
environments. Kalhor argues that the absence of robust cybersecurity measures 
can expose sensitive student data, especially in immersive technologies where 
real-time interactions are common (Kalhor & Das, 2023).
3. Teacher Training and Readiness: While VR and LLMs show promise, their 
effectiveness heavily relies on teacher readiness. Rahman emphasizes that many 
educators lack sufficient training to utilize these technologies effectively, leaving 
a gap in practical application (Rahman & Watanobe, 2023).
4. Cognitive and Physical Fatigue: Prolonged exposure to immersive environments 
can lead to fatigue and disengagement among students. Studies such as Souchet 
underline the need for"healthy interactions"to mitigate the risk of overreliance 
on VR, which may negatively impact learners’well-being (Souchet et al., 2023).
5. Accessibility Gaps: Technologies like VR and AR often overlook the needs of 
students with severe disabilities. Creed highlights the challenges of designing 
universally accessible interfaces that cater to a diverse range of physical and 
cognitive abilities (Creed et al., 2023).
While the limitations outlined above highlight key barriers to effectively adopting 
these technologies, they also present opportunities for targeted interventions. The

4.2  Recommendations
To ensure the effective integration of VR, AR, and LLMs in Special Education, a 
strategic approach is required. By adopting a structured framework, focusing on 
inclusion, teacher support, and collaboration, these technologies can address diverse 
educational needs. This ensures decisions are made sensibly and efficiently, foster -
ing inclusive, adaptive, and ethical learning environments. Some notable recommen-
dations on the frameworks are reported below:
 1. Inclusion and Support for All SEN Students
• Best Practices and Guidelines: Adopt usability and accessibility principles 
to ensure SEN students receive appropriate assistance.
• Fulfillment of Inclusion: All educational tools and methodologies must pri-
oritize full inclusion for SEN students.
 2. Teacher Well-being and Emotional Stability
• Support for Teachers: LLM-based tools should prioritize the well-being of 
teachers, ensuring they are emotionally stable and equipped with the neces-
sary knowledge.
• Emotional Advocacy: Tools must be designed to alleviate emotional crises 
that impact classroom stability, promoting a supportive environment for both 
teachers and students.
 3. LLM Integration in Educational Settings
• Roles of LLMs: LLMs can act as companions, co-learners, digital twins, vir -
tual assistants (VAs), and more.
• Character Qualities: Any virtual character should embody morality, warmth, 
empathy, and trustworthiness to build reliable relationships with students and 
teachers.
 4. Real-World Learning in Virtual Reality (VR)
• Development of Pedagogies and Scenarios: Create flexible, real-world 
learning activities and pedagogies using VR, with LLMs providing assistance 
or leading the activities.
• Diverse Educational Themes: Incorporate a variety of educational themes, 
such as Arts and physical education, catering to the diverse interests of SEN 
students.
• Additional Options: Offer supplementary choices to accommodate the var -
ied interests and needs of SEN students.
 5. Data Privacy and Protection
19166 Education and Information Technologies (2025) 30:19141–19181
• Privacy Protocols: Ensure the establishment of robust authentication pro-
tocols and data protection regulations to safeguard the private information 
shared by parents, instructors, and students.
 6. Multilingual and Multimodal Interaction
• Improved Interaction: Implement tools that are multilingual and multimodal 
to enhance the quality of interaction for diverse learners.
 7. Global Research and Collaboration
• Global Research Platform: Virtual environments (VEs) can serve as a 
research platform, enabling global interaction and collaboration among SEN 
students and educators.
 8. Real-Time Interaction in Multiuser Environments
• Enhancement of LLMs: Further develop LLMs to facilitate real-time inter -
action between users in a multiuser setting, ensuring seamless communica-
tion.
 9. Clarification of VR and LLM Capabilities
• Educational Support: Clearly define the extent to which VR and LLMs can 
assist SEN students in their educational journey and personal development.
 10. Establishment of a Central Framework
• Guided Values: The main framework should be grounded in social and moral 
values, government policies, and supported by research from the Scientific 
Community.
 11. Cross-Domain Partnerships
• Scientific Collaboration: Foster partnerships across various scientific 
domains to establish the core principles guiding the design and implementa-
tion of educational tools (Castro-Kemp & Samuels, 2022).
Accessibility and trustworthiness in learning environments are essential, with 
face-to-face learning, differentiated strategies, and teamwork as inclusive edu-
cational tools. Immersive Technologies and LLMs in Special Education raise the 
demand for cross-sector, transdisciplinary partnerships focusing on children’s edu-
cational needs (Castro-Kemp & Samuels, 2022; Rapport et al., 2004).
In addition to these immediate recommendations, there is a pressing need for 
further research to address unresolved challenges and to expand on the opportuni-
ties identified in this study. The following section outlines key future directions for 
advancing this field.
4.3  Future directions
The future of integrating Immersive Technologies and LLMs in Special Education 
is promising but requires focused research and innovation. By addressing existing

cational practices, making them more inclusive and adaptive. Below are some key 
future directions, which can potentially expand the research:
• Strategies for Unifying Typically Developed and SEND Students: Future 
research should investigate strategies to achieve unity by fostering meaningful 
collaboration and interaction between typically developed children and SEND 
students in inclusive environments.
• Integration of Sensory-Friendly AI-Powered VLEs: Sensory-friendly AI-
powered VLEs should be thoroughly researched to determine their effectiveness 
in genuinely aiding SEND students to fully interact and engage within a learning 
environment.
• Development of Daily Life Skills Training Modules: Future work should 
explore how these technologies can empower SEN students by enhancing their 
independence and preparing them for everyday challenges.
• Implementation of Practical Interventions: Future studies should prioritize the 
development of specific, practical interventions that translate theoretical research 
into actionable solutions, such as tailored software, prompting tools, or immer -
sive applications powered by LLMs, including VR/AR technologies, avatars, or 
digital twins, to address the diverse needs of SEND students.
• Quantitative Research and Feedback-Driven Refinements: Future research 
should focus on gathering quantitative data to assess the impact of these technol-
ogies on teachers, parents, and SEND students, while systematically incorporat-
ing feedback from stakeholders to refine and improve educational tools, ensuring 
they remain effective, ethical, and aligned with real-world needs.
5  Conclusion
VR and LLMs in Special Education as an"effective intervention"should be applied 
with respect and"warmth"to students’ uniqueness (Humphrey et  al., 2013; Rach-
mawati et al., 2016). Teachers embracing the call and trained in inclusive learning 
strategies, as qualified educators could foster inclusion (Engsig & Johnstone, 2015; 
Paju et  al., 2016; Tometten et  al., 2021). General Pedagogical Knowledge (GPK) 
creates effective classroom interactions and VR and LLMs could significantly con-
tribute, making engagement from stakeholders, developers, and researchers vital 
(Lauermann & König, 2016). This thematic analysis provides a comprehensive 
understanding of the integration of VR, AR, and LLMs in special education by 
identifying key themes across the literature. The identified themes highlight both 
the potential benefits and challenges of using these technologies to support students 
with special educational needs, as well as the need for a stable framework in inte-
grating these technologies.
